Award.AwardTitle: Improving Understanding of Convection Initiation in Nocturnal Environments During PECAN (Plains Elevated Convection at Night) Using High-Resolution Ensemble Data Assimilation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nocturnal thunderstorms in the central United States provide rainfall for productive agricultural regions but also can pose hazards to lives and property through flooding and severe winds. In 2015, NSF funded a large group of scientists to collect data on these nighttime thunderstorms. This award will make use of that data by conducting very small scale numerical modeling studies to determine what initially triggers the thunderstorms, a process known as convective initiation. The research has the potential to improve understanding and modeling of these events, giving forecasters more information about when and where thunderstorms may happen. The award would also contribute to human resource development by funding an early-career researcher, providing an opportunity for an undergraduate student to participate in a research project, and allowing the researcher to develop a seminar course based on the field campaign.

The Plains Elevated Convection at Night (known colloquially as PECAN) field campaign was conducted in the Great Plains region in June and July of 2015. The campaign included numerous observational platforms, such as mobile radars, aircraft, vertical profilers and surface instrumentation. In this project the researcher intends to assimilate data from the campaign into an ensemble with nested mesoscale and convection-resolving grids. The primary focus of the research is to accurately reproduce the evolution of the nocturnal mesoscale environment in which convective initiation occurs and to determine which specific small- and large-scale processes result in parcels lifted to their level of free convection. The ensemble data assimilation experiments will employ the WRF-ARW and the Data Assimilation Research Testbed (DART) ensemble analysis software configured as an Ensemble Adjustment Kalman Filter. Fifty ensemble members will be used and the researcher plans to employ a triple nested model grid strategy with the finest grid spacing of 0.4 to 0.6km. In addition to the work on identifying processes triggering nocturnal convection, the researcher will also conduct forecast sensitivity experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For decades, atmospheric scientists have studied the formation thunderstorms that occur in the afternoon resulting from the sun warming and destabilizing the atmosphere near the ground. However, thunderstorms frequently also form at night, sourced from unstable air aloft that is not a direct result of solar heating but lifted into cloud base by different forcing mechanisms than during the day. The exact details of the initiation of nocturnal thunderstorms remains a poorly understood process and offers a large forecasting impact because evening thunderstorms often organize into large weather systems responsible for a significant hydrological and sometimes severe weather impact over the central and eastern United States. To improve our physical understanding and forecasting capability of nocturnal thunderstorms, the Plains Elevated Convection at Night (PECAN) field experiment studied environments supporting thunderstorms in the overnight hours by deploying a host of special research weather instruments in the central U.S. Plains from June-July 2015. These instruments included weather radars, radiosonde weather balloons, vertical atmospheric profilers, surface stations, and research aircraft to improve observed details of nocturnal thunderstorm environments beyond those possible with weather observations routinely collected by the national weather service.

 

We assimilated observations into a numerical weather model covering the central U.S. to reproduce the environments in which nocturnal thunderstorms formed during PECAN. Our method differs from traditional weather prediction models in that, in addition to assimilating routine data used by the national weather service, we also incorporated many novel data sets collected during PECAN that resolve the environments surrounding nocturnal storm formation in great detail. Most uniquely, we assimilated clear air radar velocity observations, which have the power to characterize large three-dimensional volumes of environmental wind that could reproduce the large-scale weather features triggering thunderstorm formation. Given the lack of precedent for the assimilation of such a large quantity of novel data sets, we conducted a significant number of forecast sensitivity analyses to assess their impact on the local environment. The complexity of the sensitivity experiment results made it quite difficult to generalize the positive and negative impacts of the observations because their incorporation did not always yield more accurate analyses and forecasts of nocturnal storm formation. This suggest that further refinement of data assimilation efforts may be required before modifying future observing strategies and incorporating novel data streams into weather forecasts.

 

We also examined a nocturnal thunderstorm initiation event that was simultaneously observed by multiple weather radars positioned in close proximity to each other. Combining air velocity measurements from multiple radars has the powerful ability to reproduce the three-dimensional wind observations surrounding the developing storm. This was a rare data set, valuable for retrieving: i) the background weather features responsible for triggering thunderstorms, and ii) the sizes of cloudy updrafts at their early formative stages, which may help to better understand the conditions in which some clouds deepen and grow to the point of becoming thunderstorms, while others do not. These radar data revealed specific small-scale (~ 5-km-wide) features in the lower atmosphere that may be precursors for identifying initiating thunderstorms. These data were also analyzed in the context of two similar events observed during the RELAMPAGO field project in Argentina, helping to improve our understanding of thunderstorm formation mechanisms in the context of weather conditions common across the globe.
